sentences.sentence: It started off as a cloudy, dreary Saturday.
I woke up with a sense of sadness for my children and wondered how we would spend our weekend without access to local playgrounds.

As we scooted around a local track, my phone began to beep incessantly with the news that a mere 24 hours later, Premier Ford had decided to reverse his decision to close playgrounds.It has been well established that outdoor transmission of COVID-19 is substantially lower than indoor transmission.
We also know that surface transmission in outdoor settings has yet to be documented.

Playgrounds and outdoor recreational facilities, such as baseball diamonds, soccer fields, tennis courts and skate parks, have never been established as a source of transmission in communities, and their importance cannot be overstated as a community resource for families, particularly those disproportionately affected by this pandemic.Access to public playgrounds and outdoor recreational facilities supports children's mental health and physical well-being.
Children who lack exposure to green spaces are more likely to develop depression and anxiety later in life.
Being outdoors has been found to boost mood, reduce insomnia and to help improve coping overall.
Higher obesity rates have been recorded during school closures as disruptions in routines result in less physical, extracurricular and outdoor activities.

We know that playgrounds and outdoor recreational facilities serve an important part in allowing children to be active and engage in play.Vaccinating 'hot spots' good, closing golf courses dumb: Reviewing the Ontario lockdown(https://nationalpost.com/news/canada/vaccinating-hot-spots-good-closing-golf-courses-dumb-reviewing-the-ontario-lockdown)Chris Selley: Ontarians finally discover a breaking point for the lockdown abuse they'll tolerate(https://nationalpost.com/opinion/chris-selley-ontarians-finally-discover-a-breaking-point-for-the-lockdown-abuse-theyll-tolerate?video_autoplay=true)In the absence of playgrounds and outdoor recreational facilities, we run the risk that families will engage in indoor socialization, which we know carries greater risk.

At this critical time, with climbing case counts, we cannot afford to stimulate "hidden" socialization that will inevitably contribute to spread.In many urban centres, playgrounds and outdoor recreational facilities may be the only source of physical activity for children in marginalized communities such as those living in apartment and housing complexes where private access to green space is limited.
These families are more likely to live in multi-generational homes with working family members participating in essential work and may therefore benefit even more from time outside engaged in play.

It is this very population that is at greatest risk of COVID-19 acquisition, rendering indoor socialization far more dangerous.Over the past year, the Ford government has asked families to avoid risky indoor spaces.
Now, the Ford government is limiting access to outdoor recreational facilities.

When we concentrate our efforts on low-risk settings with a focus on restricting outdoor interactions, we create confusion around legitimate risk, we contribute to lockdown fatigue, we re-direct social interactions indoors and we divert attention away from real risk.
Instead, we must advocate for paid sick days for essential workers, a vaccine strategy prioritizing hot spots and robust testing and tracing in hard hit areas.

Closing playgrounds and outdoor recreational facilities should never be part of our pandemic response.The decision to keep outdoor recreational facilities closed cannot be made on the notion that it is better to be "safe than sorry".
We need to balance the potential benefits of a decision with the inherent harms.
Here, we have a decision with extremely unlikely benefits in disease prevention but with very real harms to children and families.
It's time to speak up for our children and families in Ontario.
It's time to open outdoor recreational facilities!Alanna Golden is a former social worker in children's mental health.
She is a practicing primary care physician in Toronto and a mother of three young children.
@COPYRIGHT=© 2021 Postmedia Network Inc. All rights reserved.

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly confident that the text is written entirely by a human.

We also know that surface transmission in outdoor settings has yet to be documented. Children who lack exposure to green spaces are more likely to develop depression and anxiety later in life. Being outdoors has been found to boost mood, reduce insomnia and to help improve coping overall. Higher obesity rates have been recorded during school closures as disruptions in routines result in less physical, extracurricular and outdoor activities. When we concentrate our efforts on low-risk settings with a focus on restricting outdoor interactions, we create confusion around legitimate risk, we contribute to lockdown fatigue, we re-direct social interactions indoors and we divert attention away from real risk.
